chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Pursue a reform package that keeps elections state-run but makes outcomes track voter preferences more closely: encourage states to replace winner-take-all with a uniform proportional formula (with a small statewide threshold to limit fragmentation) or, if preferred, join a national popular-vote compact once clear legal triggers are met. Pair any structural change with nationwide minimum standards for voter access, paper-backed ballots, transparent chain-of-custody, and automatic risk-limiting audits plus clear recount rules. Implement changes on a set timeline with bipartisan oversight and periodic review so legitimacy improves without abrupt constitutional disruption.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: A consensus reform is to keep states administering elections while reducing winner‑take‑all distortions by encouraging proportional or district‑based allocation of electors (with fair, nonpartisan districting) and allowing an interstate popular‑vote compact where states choose it. Pair any structural change with clear national minimum standards for ballot access, paper‑based verification, recount triggers, and routine post‑election audits to strengthen trust. Phase reforms in with bipartisan oversight and transparent rules so campaigns must compete in more places and close outcomes are easier for voters in every state to accept.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A unifying reform would keep states administering elections but make presidential outcomes track the voters more closely by reducing winner‑take‑all—through proportional elector allocation (with a small statewide bonus) or an interstate popular‑vote compact that only takes effect once enough states join. To protect small and rural states while boosting confidence, pair any change with national minimum standards for voter access, paper ballots, transparent audits, and clear recount triggers, plus nonpartisan districting if district methods are used. Phasing reforms in with bipartisan oversight can reduce swing‑state dominance while making close results easier for people across parties to accept.
